title: Why do people who can't sing don't realize they can't sing? Is their singing always on key in their minds? - Quora

response.answer_text: “On key” isn’t the most apt phrase. That’s a fun thing I’ve learned at music school. At least, fun fact for me, pedantic correction for you. A better phrase would be “in tune.” Singing “off key” means singing Bbs instead of Bs, or singing Gs instead of F#s. Most people who are “bad” at singing aren’t that far off. A lot of the time, they’re singing a G, not an F#, it’s just a bit flat. Not flat enough to be an F#, but enough that it sounds really, really, wrong. But a lot of the time, it’s not even the intonation! No, you could sing with great intonation, and still really, really suck. Myself, for instance. I took four years of sight-singing classes, and I can say, fairly accurately, that I can, with practice, sing all the right notes to a song, with pretty solid intonation. Not perfect, but not bad. However, my tone isn’t especially good. And a lot of the time, if I’m just singing for fun and happen to record it, I notice that my diction isn’t always clear or consistent. Those are the biggest issues. It’s not the intonation, and rarely the intervals, unless they’re especially hard to sing- it’s tone and diction. Those both take a lot of practice, preferably with a skilled teacher. My sight-screeching professor was a horn player, not a singer- he had a damn good ear for pitch, but tone and diction weren’t his specialties. (Neither was “understanding human voice types.” I swear that man thought there were just two- you were either a Man Singer, or a Lady Singer, tenor and soprano, respectively. Basses and altos had no room in his class, no sirree. We suffered together in silence and sang everything down an octave really quietly so he wouldn’t notice and ask us to “sing in the right octave.”) I’ve considered taking voice lessons, though, for a semester. I do enjoy singing, and I think it’d be worth it to work on my tone and diction. Being good at those two things is the difference between an “okay” singer and a really good one, and singing with good tone will also help keep your voice healthy and strong- bad tone stems largely from bad singing habits that can damage your voice in the long run. I’m sure an actual singer could provide more and better advice than I can, but I’d definitely say that singing “off key” isn’t the problem, 90% of the time.

I cannot sing alone, and I’m not much better in a crowd. I’m going to guess that most people who can’t sing know that they could never be a soloist, even at a family gathering. And there are also people that are tone deaf when it comes to their singing and really have no idea that they’re missing the note. (I’m tone deaf when it comes to my singing, I truly don’t know that I’m not hitting the note). However, I’ve been told, and accepted that I’m not a singer. But I will sing on occasion, hardly ever in public, and I do so because I enjoy it. Also, if you happen to hear me and dislike it, I’m not going to care. Not every one has the self-confidence to not care that someone doesn’t like their singing. So, please be nice and not complain, they most likely know they’re bad, but they’re having fun. Let them have fun.
